message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The Logic of Conditional Doxastic Actions
Paper Abstract: We present a logic of conditional doxastic actions, obtained by incorporating ideas from belief revision theory into the usual dynamic logic of epistemic actions. We do this by reformulating the setting of Action-Priority Update (see Baltag and Smets, 2008) in terms of conditional doxastic models, and using this to derive general reduction laws for conditional beliefs after arbitrary actions.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Dynamic Logic in Computer Science:

## Overview

In logic, philosophy, and theoretical computer science, dynamic logic is an extension of modal logic capable of encoding properties of computer programs.

## Key Characteristics

The syntax of dynamic logic contains a language of propositions (like "the ground is dry") and a language of actions (like "it rains"). The core modal constructs include one that states that after performing action a the proposition p should hold, and another that states that after performing action a it is possible that p holds.

## History and Development

Dynamic logic was developed by Vaughan Pratt in 1974 in notes for a class on program verification as an approach to assigning meaning to Hoare logic.(no content)Dexter Kozen is one of the fathers of dynamic logic.

## Applications

The action logic is expressive enough to encode programs. For an arbitrary program, a formula encodes the correctness of the program, making dynamic logic more general than Hoare logic.(no content)Beyond its use in formal verification of programs, dynamic logic has been applied to describe complex behaviors arising in linguistics, philosophy, AI, and other fields.

## Related Variants

Dynamic epistemic logic (DEL) is a logical framework dealing with knowledge and information change. Typically, DEL focuses on situations involving multiple agents and studies how their knowledge changes when events occur.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Belief Revision"

Links: [{"title":"Belief revision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belief_revision"},{"title":"Category:Belief revision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Belief_revision"},{"title":"Conservatism (belief revision) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservatism_(belief_revision)"},{"title":"Critical rationalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Critical_rationalism"},{"title":"Triune continuum paradigm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Triune_continuum_paradigm"},{"title":"Peter Gärdenfors - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_G%C3%A4rdenfors"},{"title":"Belief - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lay_theory"}]

Here are the search results for "Belief Revision":

## Overview

Belief revision (also called belief change) is the process of changing beliefs to take into account a new piece of information.(no content)The logical formalization of belief revision is researched in philosophy, in databases, and in artificial intelligence for the design of rational agents.

## Key Operations

Revision differs from merging in that revision is done when the new belief to incorporate is considered more reliable than the old ones; therefore, consistency is maintained by removing some of the old beliefs.(no content)Merging is a more general operation, in that the priority among the belief sets may or may not be the same.

## The AGM Framework

The AGM postulates (named after their proponents Alchourrón, Gärdenfors, and Makinson) are properties that an operator that performs revision should satisfy in order for that operator to be considered rational.

## Two Approaches

The foundational approach to belief revision is related to foundationalism in philosophy, and according to this approach, retracting a non-derived piece of knowledge should lead to retracting all its consequences that are not otherwise supported (by other non-derived pieces of knowledge).(no content)The coherentist approach aims at restoring the coherence (consistency) among all beliefs, both self-standing and derived ones.

The search results also show that conservatism or conservatism bias refers to the tendency to revise one's belief insufficiently when presented with new evidence.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Epistemic Logic"

Links: [{"title":"Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemic_modal_logic"},{"title":"Dynamic epistemic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_epistemic_logic"},{"title":"Doxastic logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Doxastic_logic"},{"title":"Epistemology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistemology"},{"title":"Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modal_logic"},{"title":"KK thesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KK_thesis"},{"title":"Masked-man fallacy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masked-man_fallacy"},{"title":"Aristotle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle"},{"title":"Talk:Modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Modal_logic"},{"title":"Talk:Epistemic modal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Epistemic_modal_logic"}]

## Epistemic Logic

Epistemic modal logic is a subfield of modal logic that is concerned with reasoning about knowledge.(no content)It has applications in many fields, including philosophy, theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, economics, and linguistics.

### Definition and Scope

Epistemic logic is a modal logic dealing with the notions of knowledge and belief, and is concerned with understanding the process of reasoning about knowledge and belief—which principles relating these notions are intuitively plausible.

### Historical Development

Jaakko Hintikka wrote "Knowledge and Belief" in 1962, the first book-length work to suggest using modalities to capture the semantics of knowledge rather than the alethic statements typically discussed in modal logic.(no content)More recently, epistemic logic has been combined with ideas from dynamic logic to create dynamic epistemic logic, which can be used to specify and reason about information change and exchange of information in multi-agent systems.

### Basic Concepts

The basic modal operator of epistemic logic, usually written K, can be read as "it is known that," "it is epistemically necessary that," or "it is inconsistent with what is known that not."(no content)Most attempts at modeling knowledge have been based on the possible worlds model, where the set of possible worlds is divided between those that are compatible with an agent's knowledge, and those that are not.

## Epistemic Logic

Epistemic modal logic is a subfield of modal logic that is concerned with reasoning about knowledge.(no content)It has applications in many fields, including philosophy, theoretical computer science, artificial intelligence, economics, and linguistics.

### Definition and Scope

Epistemic logic is a modal logic dealing with the notions of knowledge and belief, and is concerned with understanding the process of reasoning about knowledge and belief—which principles relating these notions are intuitively plausible.

### Historical Development

Jaakko Hintikka wrote "Knowledge and Belief" in 1962, the first book-length work to suggest using modalities to capture the semantics of knowledge rather than the alethic statements typically discussed in modal logic.(no content)More recently, epistemic logic has been combined with ideas from dynamic logic to create dynamic epistemic logic, which can be used to specify and reason about information change and exchange of information in multi-agent systems.

### Basic Concepts

The basic modal operator of epistemic logic, usually written K, can be read as "it is known that," "it is epistemically necessary that," or "it is inconsistent with what is known that not."(no content)Most attempts at modeling knowledge have been based on the possible worlds model, where the set of possible worlds is divided between those that are compatible with an agent's knowledge, and those that are not.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about Doxastic Logic:

## Definition and Etymology

Doxastic logic is a type of logic concerned with reasoning about beliefs.(no content)The term doxastic derives from the Ancient Greek δόξα (doxa, "opinion, belief").

## Notation and Terminology

Typically, a doxastic logic uses □, often written "B", to mean "It is believed that", or when relativized to a particular agent s, "It is believed by s that".

## Relationship to Other Logics

Doxastic logic is closely related to epistemic logic. The logic of belief is called doxastic logic. It falls within the broader category of modal logic systems used for reasoning about knowledge, belief, obligation, and related concepts.

## Key Concepts

The field examines various types of reasoners and their belief systems:

- An unstable reasoner is one who believes that they believe some proposition, but in fact does not believe it. This is just as strange a psychological phenomenon as peculiarity; however, an unstable reasoner is not necessarily inconsistent.

- A type 1 reasoner has a complete knowledge of propositional logic i.e., they sooner or later believe every tautology/theorem, and their set of beliefs (past, present and future) is logically closed under modus ponens.

## Applications

Doxastic logic provides formal frameworks for analyzing belief reasoning in philosophical contexts, including examination of paradoxes and the logical properties of rational belief systems.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
